t: Proverbs 18
A*pn man who isolates himself seeks his own desire; He*ld rages against all wise judgment.
A*ln fool has no delight in understanding, But*ld in expressing his own heart.
When*ln the wicked comes, contempt comes also; And*ld with dishonor comes*i reproach.
The*ln words of a man’s mouth are*i deep waters; The*ld wellspring of wisdom is*i a flowing brook.
It*iln is*i not good to show partiality to the wicked, Or*ild to overthrow the righteous in judgment.
A*ln fool’s lips enter into contention, And*ld his mouth calls for blows.
A*ld fool’s mouth is*i his destruction, And*ld his lips are*i the snare of his soul.
The*ld words of a talebearer are*i like tasty trifles, And*ld they go down into the inmost body.
He*ln who is slothful in his work Is*ld a brother to him who is a great destroyer.
The*ln name of the Lord*s is*i a strong tower; The*ld righteous run to it and are safe.
The*ld rich man’s wealth is*i his strong city, And*ld like a high wall in his own esteem.
Before*ln destruction the heart of a man is haughty, And*ld before honor is*i humility.
He*ln who answers a matter before he hears it,*i It*ld is*i folly and shame to him.
The*ln spirit of a man will sustain him in sickness, But*ld who can bear a broken spirit?
The*ln heart of the prudent acquires knowledge, And*ld the ear of the wise seeks knowledge.
A*ln man’s gift makes room for him, And*ld brings him before great men.
The*ln first one*i to plead his cause seems*i right, Until*ld his neighbor comes and examines him.
Casting*ln lots causes contentions to cease, And*ld keeps the mighty apart.
A*ln brother offended is*i harder*i to*i win*i than a strong city, And*ld contentions are*i like the bars of a castle.
A*ln man’s stomach shall be satisfied from the fruit of his mouth; From*ild the produce of his lips he shall be filled.
Death*ln and life are*i in the power of the tongue, And*ld those who love it will eat its fruit.
He*iln who*i finds a wife finds a good thing,*i And*ld obtains favor from the Lord.*s
The*ln poor man*i uses entreaties, But*ld the rich answers roughly.
A*ln man who*i has*i friends must himself be friendly, But*ld there is a friend who*i sticks closer than a brother.
